subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 17th January 2020: Week’s rally ends at fresh ATHs; strong US Housing Starts and Chinese GDP
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 17th January 2020: Week’s rally ends at fresh ATHs; strong US Housing Starts and Chinese GDP

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Dollar up, Crude flat/up

* REAR VIEW: Strong Housing Starts outweighs cooling Permits, mixed UoM prelim. Survey and weak IP; China grow concerns eased, for now; new BA 737 issue

* WEEK IN FOCUS: MON: PBoC Loan Prime Rate Setting, Japanese Industrial Output, German PPI, Eurogroup Meeting, Martin Luther King Day. TUE: Davos Begins (21st-24th January), BoJ Monetary Policy Decision, UK Labour Market Report, German ZEW, Eurozone Economic Sentiment, Canadian Manufacturing Sales. WED: BoC Monetary Policy Decision, Canadian CPI, South African CPI, Japanese Trade Balance, US House Price Index, Existing Home Sales. THU: ECB & Norges Bank Monetary Policy Decisions, Australian Labour Market Report, New Zealand and Japanese CPI, BoJ Minutes (December), CBRT Minutes. FRI: EZ and US Flash PMIs, Canadian Retail Sales, Chinese New Year (Mainland closed 24th-30th January). To download the report, please click here.

* CENTRAL BANK WEEKLY: PREVIEWING: BoJ, ECB, BoC, Norges. REVIEWING: BoE, Fed, SARB, CBRT, BoK. To download the report, please click here.

 

* US HOUSING STARTS & BUILDING PERMITS (DEC): Housing Starts rose by 16.9% to 1.608mln in December, above the expected 1.375mln and the upwardly revised prior of 1.375mln, taking the figure to its highest level since December 2006. Wells Fargo notes that big jumps are not uncommon in December, with large seasonal adjustments normal, especially when weather is mild, as it has been this time around. The bank notes the strong pick up in both single-family starts (+11.2%) and multi-family starts (+29.8%), which even if trimmed in later revisions, still marks a strong Q4 for homebuilding. Meanwhile, Building Permits printed 1.416mln, below the expected 1.468mln and down 3.9% from the prior 1.474mln. Wells draws our attention to the generally strong H2 for both permits and starts, which even if the trend begins to stabilize, 2020 should still print sizeable Y/Y gains.

* UNI OF MICHIGAN (PRELIM.): Headline sentiment in January ticked down slightly to 99.1 from 99.3, more or less in line with estimates for a decline to 99.2. BMO highlight the current assessment was the highest since December 2018, which is unsurprising given unemployment at a record low. Expectations saw a deeper decline than the headline to start the month, falling to 88.3 from 88.9, despite missing estimates for pick up to 89. However, the conditions surprised to the upside printing 115.8 from 115, whilst beating estimates for a print of 115. BMO Capital highlight the survey showed yet another month of resilience with equities continuing to print record highs and a tight labour market. The latest inflation expectations saw both the 1-year and 5-year metric at 2.5%, picking up from 2.3 and 2.2%, respectively. 

* US INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION (DEC): Fell by 0.3%, below the expected -0.2%, reversing from the prior rise of 0.8%, which was revised lower from 1.1%; manufacturing output rose by 0.2% (exp. -0.2%, prev. 1%) and capacity utilisation stood at 77.0% (exp. 77.1%, prev. 77.4%). Capital Economics notes the slump was “entirely due to a weather-related slump in utilities output,” where warmer than usual weather hindered demand for utilities, although cites the rest of the report as “encouraging”, specifically the 1.3% growth in mining output. The consultancy said the manufacturing beat surprised it given the reported fall in employee hours, but notes the annualized output still contracted by 1% overall in Q4, although the data suggests the worst could be over for the sector; more broadly, “although we doubt China will succeed in raising purchases of US goods by nearly as much as the Phase One trade deal suggests, the factory sector should still benefit from at least a modest recovery in exports to China over the coming months.”

* CHINA GDP (Q4), IP AND RETAIL SALES (DEC): China’s GDP expanded 6.1% in 2019, which marked the slowest pace of growth since 1990, but still lies within the nation’s 6.0%-6.5% annual growth target. The Q4 number printed in-line with forecast at 6.1%. CapEco, referring to their China Activity Proxy, notes that this points to slower growth of circa 5.5% last year, albeit suggests that economic activity has stabilised. Monthly Chinese data appears to have improved ahead of 2020 - Chinese December industrial production topped forecasts at 6.9%, rising from 6.2% against expectations for a decline to 5.9% - driven by firmer external demand. “But faster output growth among state-owned firms suggests that domestic demand also improved.” CapEco notes. Moreover, December retail sales also printed on the rosier side at 8.0%, surpassing forecasts of 7.9%. SocGen acknowledged that retail sales growth was steady, “indicating still pretty resilient consumers despite growing downward pressure on the labor market”, and downside risks to the economy is diminishing especially given the Phase 1 deal signed earlier this week, which offers policymakers comfort to stick with measures easing approach; SocGen concluded.

* FED: The White House announced President Trump will nominate Judy Shelton, former US Executive Director for European Bank of Reconstruction and Development, and Christopher Waller, St. Louis Fed Executive Vice President and Research Director to the board of governors. NEC Director Kudlow announced that the two were nominate by Trump because they believe faster economic growth does not cause inflation, whilst adding the two should have no problem getting confirmation. Note that Shelton has received scrutiny due to previous policy stances – extreme monetary hawkishness - that seem to be at odds with the “Trump friendly” easy monetary policy she has been touting more recently. Fed’s Harker (Voter, Neutral) reiterated he expects the US economy to grow ~2% this year (in-line with Fed’s median view) and for inflation to reach the Fed’s 2% target. Harker also noted the US Labour market is outperforming forecasts, with low unemployment and workers coming off the side-lines. However, he reiterated the fed’s line that the global slowdown, trade uncertainty is holding back business investment, as are geopolitical tensions. On the repo-markets, he reiterated that they have worked to calm money markets.

* WTI (H0) SETTLED USD 0.05 HIGHER AT USD 58.58/BBL; BRENT (H0) SETTLED USD 0.23 HIGHER AT USD 64.85/BBL. The crude benchmarks traded subdued on Friday, marking a small loss on the week, despite Chinese growth failing to dip below the key 6% Y/Y figure in the latest quarter. The China data supported prices in the Asian and European session although they reversed course later as US participants came to their desks and Europeans closed out for the weekend. Some additional pressure was exerted on the crude complex after the US Baker Hughes rig count reported the first rise in oil rigs in a month: oil rigs +14 at 673, natgas +1 at 120 and total rigs +15 at 796 rigs. A cloud of concern grew somewhat on China’s pledge of additional US energy purchases amid Sinopec announcing it is to review its USD 16bln gas deal with US’ Cheniere (LNG), citing lower gas prices than when the deal was first announced. Elsewhere, Norway's preliminary December oil production stood at 1.759mln BPD vs. prev. 1.711mln BPD; Schlumberger (SLB) CEO said on the earnings call that US production growth should slow "significantly" this year; Eastern Libyan protestors have entered the Zueitina oil port and announced its closure, according to a port engineer.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H0) SETTLED 3+ TICKS LOWER AT 129-01+. The T-Note sold off as the US session got underway, with a new US 20-year bond unveiling, strengthening US Dollar and decent housing data weighing on duration. The 10-year yield found resistance at just below 1.85%, before retreating somewhat in the latter end of the session. Note that the long bond saw the most selling pressure earlier in the session on the back of the US Treasury announcing it would be increasing its maturity offerings with a new 20-year bond, to launch in 2020. By settlement, the Treasury curve was steeper, with the 2-year yield little changed whilst the 30-year yield was 3bps higher. More broadly, the T-Note future settled little changed on the week, where participants digested a slew of factors, including another strong week of corporate issuance, the Phase 1 deal signing and a mixed bag of data (lacklustre CPI against firm retail sales), all in the background of US equity bourses continuing to push to new all-time-highs.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.34% at 3,328, NDX +0.53% at 9,174, DJI +0.17% at 29,348.

* SECTORS: Materials +0.48%, IT +0.71%, Communication +0.89%, Industrials 0.00%, Financials +0.43%, Staples +0.25%, Utilities +0.76%, Discretionary +0.28%, Energy -0.66%, Health Care +0.06%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Wal-Mart (WMT) was pressured after WSJ reported it is considering a US management re-shuffle following the holiday period, which saw many retailers report poor figures, with some attributing the delayed Thanksgiving. Boeing (BA) sold off after ABC reported its 737 flight computers could not talk to each other at the start up in a test flight, although it is unclear how long the fix will take. Boeing responded noting they are working on fixing the latest software issue with the FAA. Tesla (TSLA) also saw downside after reports it is being reviewed by the US Auto Safety Agency to seek an investigation into 500k vehicles for sudden unintended acceleration, according to a government document. Alphabet (GOOGL) surpassed USD 1trln market cap just before yesterday’s close and continued its gain driving outperformance in its Sector. Energy was a large underperformer following a decline in natgas prices which weighed on producers EQT Corp. (EQT), Chesapeake (CHK), and to a lesser extent, Exxon Mobil (XOM). Qualcomm (QCOM) saw an upgrade from Citi, who boosted its forecasts on the name as the “long awaited 5G ramp begins to take shape”. On the earnings front, truckers were sold off after poor earnings from JB Hunt (JBHT) and Expeditor (EXPD), where the latter also reported poor guidance. Meanwhile, State Street (STT) had strong figures and Citizens Financial (CFG) benefited from a dividend increase, and Regions Financial (RF) was hit on a slight miss on earnings, and a decline in NIM.

* FINANCIAL EARNINGS: The majority of banks performed well with JPM, C, BAC, GS and MS reporting exceptional FICC revenues. Equity performance however was slightly underwhelming, where JPM were the only bank to beat street estimates, whereas C, BAC and GS missed estimates; MS was in line.  The strong FICC revenues seemingly offset the costs associated with lower rates after the Fed cut three times hurting its commercial banking businesses. Click here for full summary.

* UK RETAIL SALES: December’s retail prints, which include the Black Friday shopping period, were in-fitting with the weak data we have seen out of the UK this week. MM significantly softer than expectations at -0.6% vs. exp. +0.5%, and unchanged from November’s level, which sparked sterling weakness and significant gilt future upside. ONS note that the data indicates a 0.05ppt drag on GDP for the period and now equates to five consecutive months with no monthly retail sales growth. On face value, adj. metrics are no better, -0.8% vs. exp. +0.7% MM and +0.7% vs. exp. +2.9% YY. However, SocGen’s Juckes highlights that this data saw a significant adjustment due to a late Black Friday, but he ‘wouldn’t bet anything against a correction (after rates have been cut?)’. Ahead of the BoE rate decision at the end of the month, the data spurred market expectations for a cut to over 70% compared to around 50% after Wednesday’s inflation numbers.

* DAILY FX WRAP (FRI.): USD continued its rally crossing last Friday’s pre-NFP high of 97.586 as the buck caught tailwinds from decent housing starts data, mixed UoM as it looked past poor industrial production. EUR fell beneath 1.11 against the dollar amid broad dollar strength which saw the 50dma give way at 1.1095, it was volatile trade around the NY cut given large option expiries around 1.1090 to 1.1105, where 2.6bln rolled off. GBP an underperformer which also supported the buck pre-data after dismal retail sales data. JPY held gains against the buck bet the cross remains above the key 110 figure, XAU was bid today finding resistance around the 1560 handle. In EMFX, the group generally performed well despite a rising dollar, apart from ZAR and TRY which traded weaker as the Lira pares back some of its gains from the prior day’s rate decision, where as the Rand continues its post rate decision decline after the SARB cut unexpectedly by 25bps in a unanimous decision.

* WEEKLY FX WRAP: The DXY has completed a round trip and more from post-NFP lows having held in just above the 97.000 handle after the official White House ceremony to sign Phase One of the US-China trade agreement, which was underwhelming as an event in itself despite all the hype. Indeed, attention swiftly turned to compliance and whether Washington rolls back/removes more tariffs, either side triggers the enforcement mechanism and Beijing actually buys the amount of US goods pledged given a caveat linked to so called ‘market conditions’ – all this even before Phase 2 negotiations start in earnest. However, the Dollar revival (index now eyeing 97.700 vs 97.584 pre-US jobs data) came via a mixture of weakness in counterpart currencies, upbeat US economic indicators (retail sales, Philly Fed and housing starts offsetting sub-forecast PPI, building permits and ip), and ultimately a steeper Treasury yield curve. content: • Report notes that the deal, initially planned in 2018, was put on hold amid growing tensions between the US and China, although now those have subsided, Sinopec is reconsidering the USD 16bln figure due to the fall in LNG prices over the period
analysis_details: As part of the Phase One agreement China agreed to purchase up to USD 52.4bln worth of additional energy products over two years, with USD 18.5bln of that on the first year upon signing. Another part is enforcement agreement, which means that if the requests from the US are not made they have the option to re-impose tariffs on the nation and withdraw from the deal.

subject: EUROPEAN PRELIMINARY CASH CLOSE: EURO STOXX 50 (+0.86%) at 3807, FTSE 100 (+0.83%) at 7673, DAX (+0.69%) at 13522, CAC 40 (+1.02%) at 6101, IBEX 35 (+1.14%) at 9682, FTSE Italia (+0.84%) at 24141, SMI (+1.41%) at 10845
Weekly FX Wrap: Phase 1 signing, dovish CBs, mixed data and currency manipulators
content:
USD

The DXY has completed a round trip and more from post-NFP lows having held in just above the 97.000 handle after the official White House ceremony to sign Phase One of the US-China trade agreement, which was underwhelming as an event in itself despite all the hype. Indeed, attention swiftly turned to compliance and whether Washington rolls back/removes more tariffs, either side triggers the enforcement mechanism and Beijing actually buys the amount of US goods pledged given a caveat linked to so called ‘market conditions’ – all this even before Phase 2 negotiations start in earnest. However, the Dollar revival (index now eyeing 97.700 vs 97.584 pre-US jobs data) came via a mixture of weakness in counterpart currencies, upbeat US economic indicators (retail sales, Philly Fed and housing starts offsetting sub-forecast PPI, building permits and ip), and ultimately a steeper Treasury yield curve.

GBP/TRY/ZAR

The Pound kicked off the week on the back foot following comments from BoE’s Vlieghe intimating that he may vote for a rate cut this month unless UK growth improved imminently and significantly. To recap, Governor Carney and MPC member Tenreyro expressed leanings towards near term easing last week, and with 2 dovish dissenters (Saunders and Haskel) already arguing for 25 bp cuts in November and December this could be enough to tip the scales. Moreover, Saunders underlined his argument for acting pre-emptively just before monthly GDP showing an unexpected contraction and IP/manufacturing output missed consensus, but the last straw came on Wednesday when headline y/y CPI slowed to 1.3% and its weakest level since November 2016. Cable hit lows of 1.2955 and Eur/Gbp highs of 0.8595 in response, but Sterling has pared some losses relative to the Euro especially. Elsewhere, the Lira and Rand have also been erratic on contrasting Turkish and SA data, geopolitical and domestic factors (Libya and Eskom/SAA respectively), but mainly in wake of January CBRT and SARB policy meetings. In short, the former delivered a ¾ point cut, within the flat to -125 bp range of estimates, but much less aggressive than prior eases in the current cycle and accompanied by a less dovish end of 2020 inflation outlook. Conversely, alongside GDP and CPI downgrades the SARB presser highlighted a significantly more benign medium term inflation projection behind the surprise 25 bp cut that undermined the Zar.

CHF/CNH

The Franc is reeling as the Greenback rebound gathers pace, but for the most part Usd/Chf and Eur/Chf have been trending lower after the US tagged Switzerland as one of the FX manipulators and investors/speculators adopted the stance that this might dissuade the SNB from intervening or at least not so readily. In contrast, albeit in exchange for explicit currency commitments in the Phase 1 pact, China was removed from list of countries deemed to be devaluing deliberately and coupled with several bullish data points the Cnh and Cny have maintained bullish momentum. Note also, the PBoC has gradually trimmed the midpoint fix while adding short and medium term finds to provide liquidity over the Lunar NY holiday period.

CAD/JPY 

Holding up better than others, the Loonie has derived independent support from a relatively upbeat BoC business outlook survey and the passing of USMCA through Congress to keep its head above 1.3080 vs its US rival, which also boosted the MXN through key technical resistance vs the Usd at one stage. However, the Yen is still on track to rack up a net loss vs the Buck on general risk on sentiment and the aforementioned Yuan strength, with Usd/Jpy above 110.00 vs 109.45 at one stage in comparison to Usd/Cnh hovering near 6.8600 vs 6.9155 or so highs.

AUD/NZD/SEK/NOK/EUR 

The Antipodean Dollars and Swedish Crowns have been volatile on swings in overall market morale, changing chart patterns/signals, cross positioning and CB vibes or commentary, with Aud/Usd veering between 0.6873 and 0.6933, Nzd/Usd from 0.6585 to 0.6665, Eur/Sek within a 10.5925-5125 band and Eur/Nok trading down to 9.8655 and up to 9.9135. However, next week could be more decisive given potentially key Aussie jobs data, NZ inflation and the first Norges Bank policy meeting of the year. On that note, ECB minutes addle little to the assessment and guidance delivered in December when new President Largarde made her debut, but Eur/Usd has recoiled from 1.1170+ to around 1.1085.

Sources familiar with the negotiations noted that the currency manipulator designation previously had no real consequences for China, albeit its removal was a symbol of goodwill from the US for Chinese officials.

Chinese Vice Premier Liu He said both US and China realise it is necessary to push US-Sino economic and trade relations back on track as soon as possible
analysis_details:
• Chinese VP Liu He earlier this week noted it is unwise to rush into the Phase Two negotiations, stating Beijing has little interest in immediately doing so; adding, we may get nothing if we rush Part Two before completing Part One., SCMP

Phase Two

  • President Trump remarked that Phase Two discussion will commence once Phase One begins, while VP Pence said negotiations for Phase Two have already begun. However, in contrast to the US’ stance, Chinese VP Liu He believes it is unwise to rush into the Phase Two negotiations, stating Beijing has little interest in immediately doing so; adding, we may get nothing if we rush Part Two before completing Part One. (SCMP). It’s also worth highlighting that China do have the option to leave the Phase One deal, which would evidently derail any further talks and likely see a return to a all-out trade war between the two nations.
  • Overall, the discrepancy on when Phase Two begins is not too pertinent at this stage, as Trump has made it clear that he is looking to wait until after the November US elections to begin the next Phase. With markets now expecting little to occur in terms of Phase Two until November; therefore, focus for the foreseeable future will be on determining China’s compliance to the deal alongside what, if any, enforceability measures are utilised

Financial Earnings Summary: JPM, C, WFC, GS, MS and more
analysis_details:
• The majority of banks performed well with JPM, C, BAC, GS and MS reporting exceptional FICC revenues. Equity performance however was slightly underwhelming, where JPM were the only bank to beat street estimates, whereas C, BAC and GS missed estimates; MS was in line.  The strong FICC revenues seemingly offset the costs associated with lower rates after the Fed cut three times hurting its commercial banking businesses.
  • As always, earnings season kicked off with the financials; JP Morgan (JPM) traded just over 1% higher on Tuesday to close the session which contributed to outperformance in the DJ against SPX & NDX given the banks 3.2% weighting. JPM beat on EPS, revenue, NII and held a strong FICC revenue. Its equity markets revenue rose 15% Y/Y to USD 1.5bln which also beat estimates due to higher revenue in prime and cash equities. JPM noted quarterly markets businesses rebounded from a challenging previous year, where a resolution of some trade issues supported client activity towards year-end. Its quarterly investment banking revenue growth was driven by higher debt and equity underwriting fees which was partially offset by lower advisory fees. Citi (C) also performed well trading with gains of 1.5% at market close on day of announcement due to beats in EPS, revenue, FICC revenue and investment banking revenue. However, its equity market revenue fell 23% to USD 516mln, although the bank announced its results included a USD 0.25/shr benefit from tax matters, even without the benefit it still beat estimates. Wells Fargo (WFC) however capped gains in the financial sector on Tuesday after seeing losses of 4% at one stage.  WFC were hit after a miss on EPS, revenue, NII and NIM, whilst ROE declined from the prior. WFC noted the EPS includes an impact of litigation accruals of a loss of USD 0.33/shr, although even on an adjusted basis it would still miss analyst expectations. Goldman Sachs (GS) were hit by a litigation charge and slightly weaker equity trading revenues, however the majority of share losses pared back shortly after Wednesday’s opening bell. Bank of America (BAC) were weighed on amid slightly soft revenues and equity trading revenues. BAC mirrored results to C and GS which saw the volatile FICC metric experience strong results, whilst equities underwhelmed. Morgan Stanley (MS) surged over 8% after it reported strong figures, particularly in FICC, although it noted its quarterly equity sales and trading revenue, which was in line with estimates, decreased in an environment characterised by lower cash market volume and lower volatility in derivatives.
  • Elsewhere, Bank of New York Mellon (BK) were hit on poor guidance. Blackrock (BLK) figures led to gains in the name after top and bottom line beats and strong AUM. Meanwhile, regional focused PNC Bank (PNC) and US Bancorp (USB) both traded in the red with lacklustre NII for the quarter, Regions Financial (RF) was hit slightly following a weak NIM. However, Citizens Financial (CFG) performed well after raising its dividend with in in-line EPS & Revenue, although reported a weak NIM, also.

17th January 2020

DOW

  • American Express Co (AXP) (Financials/Consumer Finance) received a positive mention from William Blair, reiterating the name with an Outperform rating following a review of its monthly data and trends in retail sales. The analyst slightly lowered his forecasts although remain above street consensus as he believes its valuation is attractive given the outlook and relative metrics to the S&P 500.
  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) had its PT upgraded to USD 280 from USD 225 by Nomura Instinet analyst Jeffrey Kvaal, whilst maintaining a neutral rating. The analyst cites iPhone 11 demand strength through Q1 and a sturdy H1 orders imply the iPhone 11 cycle will stay solid throughout the year, adding wearables “should add some icing to the cake”. However, the analyst has questioned the 5G cycle enthusiasm. However, Morgan Stanley also increased its PT on the name to USD 368 from USD 296 to reflect smartphone replacement cycles and the 5G upgrade.
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) had its PT lowered at Cannacord to USD 350 from USD 370, BA closed at USD 332.04 yesterday. The analyst maintained a hold rating on the name as he continues to be cautious on the name due to mid term risk to margins and poor cash flow expectations
  • International Business Machines (IBM) (Information Technology/IT Consulting & Other Services) has been downgraded to Equal Weight from Overweight at Morgan Stanley by analyst Kathryn Huberty, providing a USD 155 PT, IBM last closed at USD 136.23. The analyst noted its CIO and Value-Added Reseller surveys point to further deceleration in 2020 IT spending. Whilst also highlighting channel checks are suggesting companies are continuing to digest excess IT capacity purchased in 2018. The analyst also lowered estimates for NetApp (NTAP), HP Enterprise (HPE) and Pure Storage (PSTG) as she forecasts hardware budget growth slowing and a rise in memory prices.

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 17th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are firmer this morning, continuing the positive tone from APAC hours
  • Sterling lags and Gilts lead core debt peers after dismal UK retail sales
  • White House officials confirmed they are planning election year stimulus which will focus on tax reductions
  • Chinese GDP printed in-line with exp. with IP and retail sales topping estimates
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Building Permits, Housing Starts, Industrial Production, JOLTS, Uni. Of Michigan, Baker Hughes, Fed’s Harker, Quarles

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded positive after taking impetus from another record-setting session on Wall St. following the recent Phase 1 deal signing and where sentiment was underpinned by encouraging earnings and data, while participants also digested a flurry of key Chinese data including GDP which grew inline with expectations. ASX 200 (+0.3%) extended on all-time highs led by broad strength in mining names including Rio Tinto despite the Co. printing weaker Q4 iron ore shipments, although Nufarm was at the other end of the spectrum with double-digit losses after it flagged weaker earnings across several segments. Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) was kept afloat by favourable currency flows, while Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (U/C) initially gained after the continued PBoC liquidity efforts and slew of tier-1 Chinese data in which GDP printed inline with expectations and both Industrial Production and Retail Sales topped estimates. However, the data showed China’s 2019 growth slowed to 6.1% from 6.6% Y/Y which was the weakest since 1990 albeit still within the official 6.0%-6.5% target range. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher in a reclaim of the 152.00 level with the rebound unfazed despite the positive risk tone and all metrics pointing to weaker results at today’s 20yr JGB auction.

PBoC injected CNY 200bln in 14-day reverse repos for a net weekly injection CNY 600bln vs. CNY 50bln drain W/W. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.8878 vs. Exp. 6.8843 (Prev. 6.8807)

Chinese GDP (Q4) Q/Q 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.5%). Chinese GDP (Q4) Y/Y 6.0% vs. Exp. 6.0% (Prev. 6.0%) Chinese GDP YTD (Q4) Y/Y 6.1% (Prev. 6.2%); slowest pace of growth since 1990. Chinese Industrial Production (Dec) Y/Y 6.9% vs. Exp. 5.9% (Prev. 6.2%) Chinese Retail Sales (Dec) Y/Y 8.0% vs. Exp. 7.8% (Prev. 8.0%)

BoK kept the 7-Day Repo Rate at 1.25% as expected, while it stated that the South Korea economy is forecast to grow at lower 2% level this year and inflation will gradually reach 1%, while it added growth is inline with previous projections and downturn in exports is likely to ease. Furthermore, BoK Governor Lee said it would be appropriate to keep policy rate above rates in advanced economies and that the rate decision was not unanimous with board members Cho and Shin the dissenters.

US

US Treasury decided it will issue 20-year bonds in H1 this year after having considering proposals including a 50-year or 100-year bond to bridge the financing budget deficit, while it reportedly expects strong demand for the new issuance. (Newswires)

White House officials confirmed they are planning election year stimulus which will focus on tax reductions. (Fox Business News)

US President Trump has announced Judy Shelton and Christopher Waller as nominees for the Fed Board of Governors, according to the White House. Trump in July noted that he would nominate the two. (Newswires/FT)

GEOPOLITICS

US Central Command said at least 11 US troops were injured in last week’s Iranian missile attack on the Al-Asad air base in Iraq. (Newswires)

China Foreign Ministry said China closely followed and monitored US warship in the Taiwan Strait, urging US to abide by China principle. (Newswires)

UK/EU

German Defence Minister Kramp-Karrenbauer suggested the EU should offer Britain “privileged third-party status” in defence and foreign policy cooperation post-Brexit following a meeting with her UK counterpart Ben Foster. (Guardian)

EU Trade Commissioner Hogan said EU wants to strengthen economic ties with US and that he had very good talks with USTR Lighthizer. Hogan also reiterated EU's plan for retaliatory tariffs over Boeing aid but also told US officials again that the EU is keen to work towards a negotiated solution on the aircraft subsidy issue. Furthermore, Hogan said the sides are still talking about digital services tax and noted agriculture is still a sticking point in tariffs cut goal although the EU is willing to explore options to break impasse and get past the sticking point. (Newswires)

French Finance Minister Le Maire says EU is making progress with the US on the digital tax issue, reiterated that the EU will retaliate if US imposes sanctions against France; has made proposals to resolve the digital tax dispute to US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and more proposals will be made this evening. (Newswires)

UK Retail Sales MM (Dec) -0.6% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. -0.6%, Rev. -0.8%); YY (Dec) 0.9% vs. Exp. 2.6% (Prev. 1.0%, Rev. 0.8%)

-        Ex-Fuel MM (Dec) -0.8% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. -0.6%, Rev. -0.8%); Ex-Fuel YY (Dec) 0.7% vs. Exp. 2.9% (Prev. 0.8%, Rev. 0.6%)

-        ONS says the retail sales data in Q4 indicating a 0.05ppt drag on GDP in the period and December was the fifth consecutive month with no MM growth in retail sales, food store sales fell the most in three years

EZ HICP Final YY (Dec) 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.3% (Prev. 1.3%)

-        HICP-X F&E Final YY (Dec) 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.4% (Prev. 1.4%)

-        HICP-X F,E,A&T Final YY (Dec) 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.3% (Prev. 1.3%)

EQUITIES

An upbeat session for European equities thus far [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.8%] with firm gains seen across the board, following on from an overall positive APAC session as sentiment remains underpinned following reassuring earnings coupled and decent data. The CAC (+1.0%) DAX (+0.8%) lead the gains in the region, with FTSE 100 joining the party following early underperformance on currency dynamics. Sectors are mostly in the green with the exception of the energy names as oil stalled not far off YTD lows and natural gas prices slump. Meanwhile, sectors leading the advances include industrials, utilities, healthcare and IT, with the latter potentially feeling some tailwind from Alphabet joining the USD 1tln market cap club. In terms of move. In terms of individual movers – heavyweight Bayer (+1.0%) remains a top gainer in the DAX after reports stated the Co. could be weeks away from settling over 75k cancer claims in relation to its Roundup weed-killer. Elsewhere, Richemont (+5.0%) shares have been bolstered by a Q3 revenue beat against the background of Hong Kong protests – thus Swatch (+1.9%) are higher in tandem. On the flip side, Casino (-7.7%) shares slumped as much as 9% at the open amid dismal prelim results and a profit warning amid the French pension reform protests, with peer Carrefour (+0.8%) initially falling in sympathy but nursing losses in recent trade.

FX

GBP - Sterling was in the ascendency ahead of ONS retail sales data for the festive month of December, with forecasts for a firm rebound in consumption bolstered by the fact that Black Friday fell within the reporting period. However, longs and anyone front-running the release on the prospect or rumour of an upside surprise were left high and dry by another bleak set of numbers. Cable duly collapsed from 1.3100+ to sub-1.3050 and Eur/Gbp spiked from around 0.8487 to circa 0.8533 and back above a big 1.2 bn option expiry at 0.8500 in the process.

USD - In stark contrast to the whipsaw moves witnessed vs the Pound, trading ranges have been relatively sedate and exemplified by the DXY sticking between narrow 97.259-396 lines in the run up to another raft of US economic releases, including housing starts, building permits, ip, manufacturing output, JOLTS and Michigan Sentiment. However, the Dollar retains an underlying bid in wake of yesterday’s upbeat data and Philly Fed survey on balance, with a significantly steeper Treasury curve on longer end supply factors also lending support.

AUD/NZD/CAD/JPY/EUR/CHF - The Aussie and Kiwi have derived a degree of positive momentum from mostly encouraging Chinese macro news overnight to pare some declines against their US counterpart and hold around or above big figures, at 0.6900 and 0.6600 respectively. Consequently, the Aud/Nzd cross is pivoting 1.0400 and could yet rebound a bit further if hefty Aud/Usd expiry interest at 0.6925 (1.3 bn) exerts some upside influence. Elsewhere, the Loonie is still meandering either side of 1.3050 and near 1.1 bn expiries from 1.3030-40, while the Yen is consolidating in a lower band below 110.00 where 1 bn expiry interest resides and the Euro remains restrained under 1.1150 amidst even bigger expiries stacked from 1.1090 to 1.1200 (totalling almost 12 bn and fairly evenly spread). Conversely, the decent Usd/Chf expiries are not that close to current levels (0.9660 or so) and the Franc failed to glean any real impetus/direction from Swiss import/export prices even though firmer or less deflationary than previously.

EM - Pretty mixed/inconclusive performances vs the Buck thus far, but the Rand has clawed back some post-SARB weakness and Lira vice-versa as oil prices rebound to the benefit of the Rouble, while the Renminbi continues to grind higher in wake of the aforementioned upbeat (overall) Chinese data.

Notable Option Expiries, NY Cut:

-        EUR/USD: 1.1090-1.1105 (2.6BLN), 1.1120-25 (2BLN), 1.1135-45 (1.1BLN), 1.1150 (2.1BLN), 1.1165-75 (1BLN), 1.1200 (3BLN)

-        EUR/GBP: 0.8500 (1.2BLN)

-        AUD/USD: 0.6855 (650M), 0.6900 (310M), 0.6925 (1.3BLN), 0.6970 (690M)

-        USD/CAD: 1.3000 (433M), 1.3030-40 (1.1BLN), 1.3150-55 (800M)

-        USD/JPY: 110.00 (1BLN), 110.15 (500M), 110.40-50 (600M), 111.00 (815M)

FIXED INCOME

Bunds and Gilts are poised just shy of best levels forged on the back of the latest in an even longer line of BoE ease inducing UK data (far from the usual seasonal spending even with Black Friday included), with the former now flat on the day vs +6 ticks at 171.78 and latter 32 ticks ahead compared to +34 ticks at best (133.76 new contract peak). However, Italian bonds are now approaching 143.00 after their recent meltdown and circa ¾ point above parity in contrast to idling US Treasuries bar the sharply underperforming long end that is making room for supply to come rather than refuelling after absorbing a new syndicated offering.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front-month futures have been lifted in recent trade in what seems to be more of a sentiment-driven move as opposed to oil-specific fundamental news. The former eyes USD 59/bbl to the upside having stalled just ahead of the psychological level, whilst the latter eclipsed USD 65/bbl. PVM notes that from this month’s oil market reports, the key takeaways are that global inventories will grow this year, with oversupply concerns continuing to persist in H1 2020, driven my rising Shale output and in-fitting with the latest US production figures with reached a record high of 13mln BPD. “In view of this, any lingering bulls ought to retreat into hibernation, remerging only in the summer when oil fundamentals shake off their bearish malaise.” – PVM states. The analysts also note that prices are underpinned after the Senate passed the USMCA trade deal yesterday but upside remains capped by concerns on whether China will live up to its promises to bolster US imports, which could bring an end to the ceasefire between the world’s two largest nations. Elsewhere, spot gold continues to consolidate from the parabolic price action seen since early December with prices currently steady just above the 1550/oz mark ahead of potential mild resistance around 1558/oz – with eyes remaining on the geopolitical landscape after US Central Command stated that 11 US troops were injured in last week’s Iranian attacks on the Al-Asad airbase, despite US President Trump claiming that there were no injuries. Copper prices meanwhile remain supported amid the overall market sentiment with price north of USD 2.85/lb, and potentially feeling some tailwinds from China’s GDP remaining within its target band.

subject: Newsquawk EU Mid Session: Gilts ramp-up on woeful retail sales as BoE cut expectations touch 70% - 17th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

An upbeat session for European equities thus far [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.8%] with firm gains seen across the board, following on from an overall positive APAC session as sentiment remains underpinned following reassuring earnings coupled and decent data. The CAC (+1.0%) DAX (+0.8%) lead the gains in the region, with FTSE 100 joining the party following early underperformance on currency dynamics. Sectors are mostly in the green with the exception of the energy names as oil stalled not far off YTD lows and natural gas prices slump. Meanwhile, sectors leading the advances include industrials, utilities, healthcare and IT, with the latter potentially feeling some tailwind from Alphabet joining the USD 1tln market cap club. In terms of move. In terms of individual movers – heavyweight Bayer (+1.0%) remains a top gainer in the DAX after reports stated the Co. could be weeks away from settling over 75k cancer claims in relation to its Roundup weed-killer. Elsewhere, Richemont (+5.0%) shares have been bolstered by a Q3 revenue beat against the background of Hong Kong protests – thus Swatch (+1.9%) are higher in tandem. On the flip side, Casino (-7.7%) shares slumped as much as 9% at the open amid dismal prelim results and a profit warning amid the French pension reform protests, with peer Carrefour (+0.8%) initially falling in sympathy but nursing losses in recent trade.

FX

GBP - Sterling was in the ascendency ahead of ONS retail sales data for the festive month of December, with forecasts for a firm rebound in consumption bolstered by the fact that Black Friday fell within the reporting period. However, longs and anyone front-running the release on the prospect or rumour of an upside surprise were left high and dry by another bleak set of numbers. Cable duly collapsed from 1.3100+ to sub-1.3050 and Eur/Gbp spiked from around 0.8487 to circa 0.8533 and back above a big 1.2 bn option expiry at 0.8500 in the process.

USD - In stark contrast to the whipsaw moves witnessed vs the Pound, trading ranges have been relatively sedate and exemplified by the DXY sticking between narrow 97.259-396 lines in the run up to another raft of US economic releases, including housing starts, building permits, ip, manufacturing output, JOLTS and Michigan Sentiment. However, the Dollar retains an underlying bid in wake of yesterday’s upbeat data and Philly Fed survey on balance, with a significantly steeper Treasury curve on longer end supply factors also lending support.

AUD/NZD/CAD/JPY/EUR/CHF - The Aussie and Kiwi have derived a degree of positive momentum from mostly encouraging Chinese macro news overnight to pare some declines against their US counterpart and hold around or above big figures, at 0.6900 and 0.6600 respectively. Consequently, the Aud/Nzd cross is pivoting 1.0400 and could yet rebound a bit further if hefty Aud/Usd expiry interest at 0.6925 (1.3 bn) exerts some upside influence. Elsewhere, the Loonie is still meandering either side of 1.3050 and near 1.1 bn expiries from 1.3030-40, while the Yen is consolidating in a lower band below 110.00 where 1 bn expiry interest resides and the Euro remains restrained under 1.1150 amidst even bigger expiries stacked from 1.1090 to 1.1200 (totalling almost 12 bn and fairly evenly spread). Conversely, the decent Usd/Chf expiries are not that close to current levels (0.9660 or so) and the Franc failed to glean any real impetus/direction from Swiss import/export prices even though firmer or less deflationary than previously.

EM - Pretty mixed/inconclusive performances vs the Buck thus far, but the Rand has clawed back some post-SARB weakness and Lira vice-versa as oil prices rebound to the benefit of the Rouble, while the Renminbi continues to grind higher in wake of the aforementioned upbeat (overall) Chinese data.

subject: Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

17th January 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly positive as they took impetus from another record-setting session on Wall St. following the recent Phase 1 deal signing and where sentiment was underpinned by encouraging earnings and data, while participants also digested a flurry of key Chinese data including GDP which grew inline with expectations. ASX 200 (+0.3%) extended on all-time highs led by broad strength in mining names including Rio Tinto despite the Co. printing weaker Q4 iron ore shipments, although Nufarm was at the other end of the spectrum with double-digit losses after it flagged weaker earnings across several segments. Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) was kept afloat by favourable currency flows, while Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) initially gained after the continued PBoC liquidity efforts and slew of tier-1 Chinese data in which GDP printed inline with expectations and both Industrial Production and Retail Sales topped estimates. However, the gains were later reversed as the data showed China’s 2019 growth slowed to 6.1% from 6.6% Y/Y which was the weakest since 1990 albeit still within the official 6.0%-6.5% target range.

FTSE 100

Rio Tinto (RIO LN) - Q4 Pilbara iron ore output 83.6mln tons vs. Prev. 86.6mln tons Y/Y, iron ore shipments 86.8mln tons vs. Prev. 87.4mln tons. Co. recognised about USD 200mln charge against 2019 underlying EBITDA on increased Escondida provisions for coal contract cancellations. (Newswires)

Vodafone (VOD LN) – Indian listed Vodafone Idea’s shares fell almost 40% during APAC trade after the Supreme Court rejected a plea by telecom operations to review a verdict that had widened the definition of adj. gross revenue. The Cos pared some losses (Vodafone Idea last down 22%) after sources noted that the Indian government was open to hear telecoms’ suggestions to help ease adj. gross revenue payments. (ET/Newswires) Vodafone Group owns 45.1% of Vodafone Idea.

Pearson (PSON LN) - The Times suggests the Co. is at risk of losing its place in the FTSE 100 after yesterday's profit warning and the resignation of its finance directors. (Times) Note, the next reshuffle is due in March

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 17th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded mostly positive after taking impetus from another record-setting session on Wall St.
  • Chinese GDP printed in-line with expectations, whilst both Industrial Production and Retail Sales topped estimates
  • China’s Global Times noted comments from an expert who suggested that China could demand that the US roll back all tariffs prior to phase two talks
  • DXY was relatively flat and held near the prior day’s highs, while its major counterparts were indecisive
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK Retail Sales, EZ CPI (F), US Building Permits, Housing Starts, Industrial Production, JOLTS, Uni. Of Michigan, Baker Hughes, Fed’s Harker, Quarles

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly positive after taking impetus from another record-setting session on Wall St. following the recent Phase 1 deal signing and where sentiment was underpinned by encouraging earnings and data, while participants also digested a flurry of key Chinese data including GDP which grew inline with expectations. ASX 200 (+0.3%) extended on all-time highs led by broad strength in mining names including Rio Tinto despite the Co. printing weaker Q4 iron ore shipments, although Nufarm was at the other end of the spectrum with double-digit losses after it flagged weaker earnings across several segments. Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) was kept afloat by favourable currency flows, while Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) initially gained after the continued PBoC liquidity efforts and slew of tier-1 Chinese data in which GDP printed inline with expectations and both Industrial Production and Retail Sales topped estimates. However, the data showed China’s 2019 growth slowed to 6.1% from 6.6% Y/Y which was the weakest since 1990 albeit still within the official 6.0%-6.5% target range. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher in a reclaim of the 152.00 level with the rebound unfazed despite the positive risk tone and all metrics pointing to weaker results at today’s 20yr JGB auction.

PBoC injected CNY 200bln in 14-day reverse repos for a net weekly injection CNY 600bln vs. CNY 50bln drain W/W. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.8878 vs. Exp. 6.8843 (Prev. 6.8807)

Chinese GDP (Q4) Q/Q 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.5%). Chinese GDP (Q4) Y/Y 6.0% vs. Exp. 6.0% (Prev. 6.0%) Chinese GDP YTD (Q4) Y/Y 6.1% (Prev. 6.2%); slowest pace of growth since 1990. Chinese Industrial Production (Dec) Y/Y 6.9% vs. Exp. 5.9% (Prev. 6.2%) Chinese Retail Sales (Dec) Y/Y 8.0% vs. Exp. 7.8% (Prev. 8.0%)

SCMP opinion piece suggested that China will stick to the Phase 1 if it maintains China’s stability and that President Xi's absence from the signing suggests Beijing is leaving it open by how much they will abide by, while China Global Times noted comments from an expert who suggested that even if China agrees to begin negotiations for a phase two agreement, it will likely demand that the US roll back all tariffs prior to talks. (SCMP/Global Times)

BoK kept the 7-Day Repo Rate at 1.25% as expected, while it stated that the South Korea economy is forecast to grow at lower 2% level this year and inflation will gradually reach 1%, while it added growth is inline with previous projections and downturn in exports is likely to ease. Furthermore, BoK Governor Lee said it would be appropriate to keep policy rate above rates in advanced economies and that the rate decision was not unanimous with board members Cho and Shin the dissenters.

UK/EU

German Defence Minister Kramp-Karrenbauer suggested the EU should offer Britain “privileged third-party status” in defence and foreign policy cooperation post-Brexit following a meeting with her UK counterpart Ben Foster. (Guardian)

EU Trade Commissioner Hogan said EU wants to strengthen economic ties with US and that he had very good talks with USTR Lighthizer. Hogan also reiterated EU's plan for retaliatory tariffs over Boeing aid but also told US officials again that the EU is keen to work towards a negotiated solution on the aircraft subsidy issue. Furthermore, Hogan said the sides are still talking about digital services tax and noted agriculture is still a sticking point in tariffs cut goal although the EU is willing to explore options to break impasse and get past the sticking point. (Newswires) 

FX

DXY was relatively flat and held near the prior day’s highs following recent strong US data, while its major counterparts were indecisive with EUR/USD clustered among more than EUR 4bln of option expiries between 1.1120-1.1150 rolling off at today’s New York cut. GBP/USD was also relatively unchanged and remained near this week’s best levels as it found support from its 200-hour MA at 1.3061. Elsewhere, USD/JPY extended above 110.00 to print its strongest since May as the positive risk tone spurred mild safe-haven outflows from the Japanese currency, while antipodeans were indecisive following the deluge of Chinese data and softer PBoC reference rate which the central bank weakened for the first time in more than a week. 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were uneventful in which WTI crude future remained rangebound near the USD 58.50/bbl level to hold on to most the prior day’s gains which had been spurred in tandem with the fresh record highs for stocks on Wall St, although price action across the energy complex lacked any excitement as participants mulled over the slew of Chinese tier-1 data releases and due to quietness on the geopolitical front. Elsewhere, gold re-approached the top of yesterday’s thin range amid a lacklustre greenback, while copper eked mild gains which was seen to be slight short-covering rather than a reaction to the Chinese data. 

GEOPOLITICS

US Central Command said at least 11 US troops were injured in last week’s Iranian missile attack on the Al-Asad air base in Iraq. (Newswires)

US 

T-Notes were offered on Thursday amid risk appetite in the wake of the Phase 1 trade deal, positive data and a strong MS earnings supporting financials. The TPLEX traded sideways in Europe, before finding offers as US participants came to the scene, then experiencing additional selling on a firm US retail sales release and strong Philly Fed Index print. The bid in equities was persistent through the session, keeping yields firmer, although a slew of FIG issuance post-earnings blackout (in additional to other ex-financials) likely helped some of the concession in later trade; by settlement, yields were around 2bps higher in the belly- and long-end. US T-note futures (H0) settled 6 ticks lower at 129-05.

US Treasury decided it will issue 20-year bonds in H1 this year after having considering proposals including a 50-year or 100-year bond to bridge the financing budget deficit, while it reportedly expects strong demand for the new issuance. (Newswires)

White House officials confirmed they are planning election year stimulus which will focus on tax reductions. (Fox Business News)

US Senate voted 89-10 to pass the USMCA deal which had already received strong bipartisan support at the House in December. (Newswires)

US President Trump has announced Judy Shelton and Christopher Waller as nominees for the Fed Board of Governors, according to the White House. Trump in July noted that he would nominate the two. (Newswires/FT)

subject: ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia stocks were mostly higher but with gains capped on slew of Chinese data including the slowest growth in around 3 decades
content: Asian equity markets traded mostly positive as they took impetus from another record-setting session on Wall St. following the recent Phase 1 deal signing and where sentiment was underpinned by encouraging earnings and data, while participants also digested a flurry of key Chinese data including GDP which grew inline with expectations. ASX 200 (+0.3%) extended on all-time highs led by broad strength in mining names including Rio Tinto despite the Co. printing weaker Q4 iron ore shipments, although Nufarm was at the other end of the spectrum with double-digit losses after it flagged weaker earnings across several segments. Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) was kept afloat by favourable currency flows, while Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) initially gained after the continued PBoC liquidity efforts and slew of tier-1 Chinese data in which GDP printed inline with expectations and both Industrial Production and Retail Sales topped estimates. However, the gains were later reversed as the data showed China’s 2019 growth slowed to 6.1% from 6.6% Y/Y which was the weakest since 1990 albeit still within the official 6.0%-6.5% target range. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher in a reclaim of the 152.00 level with the rebound unfazed despite the positive risk tone and all metrics pointing to weaker results at today’s 20yr JGB auction.

subject: ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia trades mostly higher after the fresh records on Wall St and as the region digests the China tier-1 data dump
content:
Asian equity markets trade positive as they take impetus from another record-setting session on Wall St. following the recent Phase 1 deal signing and where sentiment was also underpinned by encouraging earnings and data, while participants also digest a flurry of key Chinese data including GDP which grew inline with expectations. ASX 200 (+0.5%) extends on record highs led by broad strength in mining names including Rio Tinto despite the Co. printing weaker Q4 iron ore shipments, although Nufarm is at the other end of the spectrum with double digit losses after it flagged weaker earnings across several segments. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) is kept afloat by favourable currency flows, while Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) are mildly positive after the PBoC continued its substantial liquidity efforts and following a slew of tier-1 Chinese data in which GDP printed inline with expectations and both Industrial Production and Retail Sales topped estimates. However, the gains are limited as the data showed China’s 2019 growth slowed to 6.1% from 6.6% the prior year which is the weakest since 1990 albeit still within the official 6.0%-6.5% target range.

In FX markets, the DXY is relatively flat and holds near the prior day’s highs following recent strong data including retail sales and Philadelphia Fed numbers, while its major counterparts are indecisive with EUR/USD clustered among more than EUR 4bln of option expiries between 1.1120-1.1150 rolling off at today’s New York cut. GBP/USD is also relatively unchanged and remains near this week’s highs as it finds support from its 200-hour MA at 1.3061. Elsewhere, USD/JPY extended above 110.00 to print its highest since May last year as the positive risk tone spurs safe-haven outflows from the Japanese currency and antipodeans are indecisive following the deluge of Chinese data and weaker PBoC reference rate, while the PBoC also weakened the reference rate for the first time in more than a week.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are relatively flat as it bides its time below the 152.00 level heading into today’s 20yr auction.

Trade

US President Trump noted that the US-China Phase One deal is also good for China and our long term relationship, while he added that USD 250bln will be coming back to US and we are now in a great position for a Phase 2 start. Furthermore, he later tweeted that US farmers are really happy with the China Phase 1 deal and soon to be signed USMCA deal. (Newswires)

USTR posted to the Federal Register that tariffs of 15% on USD 120bln of Chinese imports will be cut to 7.5% on February 14th, according to FBN's Lawrence. (Twitter) Note: This is the tariff reduction that had been announced last month alongside the Phase 1 agreement and decision to not proceed with the tariffs that had been scheduled for December 15th.

Chinese Vice Premier Liu He said it is unwise to rush into the Phase 2 negotiations and that Beijing has little interest in immediately doing so, while he added we may get nothing if we rush Part 2 before completing Part 1 according to SCMP. In related news, Global Times also noted that China requires time to assess the Phase 1 agreement and other factors before beginning Phase 2 and that US officials are getting ahead of themselves claiming talks are underway citing a Government Adviser and Expert. (SCMP/Twitter)

China Global Times article noted comments from an expert who suggested that even if China agrees to begin negotiations for a phase two agreement, it will likely demand that the US roll back all tariffs prior to talks. (Global Times)

SCMP opinion piece suggested that China will stick to the Phase 1 if it maintains China’s stability and that President Xi's absence from the signing suggests Beijing is leaving it open by how much they will abide by. (SCMP)
